newsitem.title: UK: Copper leads markets up, LME ends in plus column.
newsitem.headline: Copper leads markets up, LME ends in plus column.

text.p: Copper prices shook off their midsession blues during more active Wednesday afternoon LME trading, pulling other metals to higher closes.
Traders said there was a knock-on affect from copper extending its move above $2,200, and zinc and nickel reached fresh highs for this current bull-run.
"They (markets) kicked into action again this afternoon, and some of the shorts got nervous," said Martin Squires of LME trader Rudolf Wiolff and Co.
Apart from copper, there was an influx of trade interest throughout the complex, while investment fund buying re-appeared in the zinc and nickel markets, he noted.

Copper's spread premiums firmed again with cash/three months whipping back above the $200 backwardation level. Nearby prompts continue to trade at or near the $23 daily LME limit - a trend seen continuing up to the Feb date two weeks away.
Earlier, February traded option declarations passed routinely, with the market falling between strikes and thus generating little followthrough excitement.
However, once the options passed by there was some fresh buying, which eventually lifted prices up to the $2,240 level by Wednesday's kerb close, up $36 from Tuesday.

Fund interest helped zinc move through the previous high and tough resistance in the mid-$1,170s, although there is further overhead supply stretching up to $1,200. Last trade was at $1,184, just off an $1,190 peak, but up $15 from Tuesday.
Nickel momentarily broke above the important chart point of $7,820 on speculative buying, before settling back to close the session at $7,810, still up $125.

Aluminium similarly advanced during the afternoon rings, but again ran into tough resistance above $1,625. Nevertheless the close at $1,632, up from an overnight $1,617.50, suggests that there will be another re-test of $1,640 soon.
Lead inched higher, with this market continuing to trade routinely, and last business was at $681, up just $3. Tin also crawled higher, and finished at $5,860, only $5 up from the overnight kerb.
The alloy market closed at a slightly higher $1,535/40 a tonne. --Martin Hayes, London Newsroom 44 171 542 8080
